subject: Investing
title: Shareholder Rights and Voting
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Shareholder Rights and Voting.

hook.text: You own 100 shares of a company. A letter arrives asking you to vote on the next board of directors.

buildup.text: Common shareholders get one vote per share on major decisions: board elections, mergers, and executive pay.

discovery.text: Proxy voting lets you vote by mail or online. Most small investors ignore it, giving insiders more power.

twist.text: Some companies issue dual-class shares. Founders keep 10 votes per share while public investors get one.

climax.text: Activist investors buy large stakes specifically to force changes through voting. Carl Icahn made a career of it.

punchline.text: Your vote is small. But ownership means you have a seat at the table.

quiz.question: What do dual-class share structures allow founders to do?
options: Maintain control with more votes per share
